title: What does the United Nations actually do?

options.label: B

title: How do dogs "see" with their noses? - Alexandra Horowitz

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about a dog's sense of smell compared to humans?

options.label: A
options.text: It can only detect scents at high concentrations.

options.label: B
options.text: It can detect scents at concentrations up to 100 million times less than what humans can detect.

options.label: C
options.text: It can only detect scents in a small area.

options.label: D
options.text: It can only detect scents in a short period of time.

multiple-choice.question: What is the vomeronasal organ responsible for detecting in dogs?
How does a dog's sense of smell help it determine the direction of a scent?

options.label: A
options.text: By using its ears to pinpoint the sound of the scent.

options.label: B
options.text: By using its whiskers to feel the direction of the scent.

options.label: C
options.text: By smelling with each nostril in stereo.

options.label: D
options.text: By smelling the scent and then looking in the direction it came from.

options.label: A
options.text: It breathes in and out through the same passage.

options.label: C
options.text: It exhales through slits at the side of its nose.

options.label: A
options.text: Takes up a small amount of relative brain area.

options.label: B
options.text: Takes up a moderate amount of relative brain area.

options.label: C
options.text: Takes up many times more relative brain area than in humans.

options.label: A
options.text: By using its ears to hear the threat.

options.label: B
options.text: By using its whiskers to feel the threat.

options.label: C
options.text: By smelling the hormones released by the threat.

multiple-choice.question: What is a dog's sense of smell capable of detecting?

options.label: A
options.text: Only scents in a small area.

options.label: C
options.text: A staggering variety of specific scents at concentrations up to 100 million times less than what humans can detect.

options.label: D
options.text: Only scents in a short period of time.

multiple-choice.question: How does a dog's sense of smell help it detect potential mates or distinguish between friendly and hostile animals?

options.label: A
options.text: By using its ears to hear the animal's vocalizations.

options.label: B
options.text: By using its whiskers to feel the animal's scent.

options.label: C
options.text: By smelling the hormones released by the animal.

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about a dog's perception compared to humans?

options.label: A
options.text: It is more immediate and visceral.

options.label: B
options.text: It is more delayed and abstract.

options.label: C
options.text: It is more rational and logical.

options.label: D
options.text: It is more emotional and intuitive.

title: How does your smartphone know your location? - Wilton L. Virgo

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why it's essential to know the time on a satellite when determining location?

options.label: A
options.text: To calculate the distance to the satellite using the formula distance = c x time.

options.label: B
options.text: To determine the speed of the satellite.

options.label: C
options.text: To know the exact location of the satellite.

options.label: D
options.text: To understand the physics behind the satellite's movement.

options.label: A

options.label: C
options.text: They rely on the transition between two energy levels of an atom.

options.label: D
options.text: They use a quartz crystal resonator.

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: What is the characteristic frequency of cesium 133 atoms?
What is the primary reason why GPS satellites rely on cesium and rubidium atoms as frequency standards?

options.label: A
options.text: To calculate the speed of the satellite.

options.label: B
options.text: To determine the location of the satellite.

options.label: C
options.text: To pinpoint the location of the smartphone.

options.label: D
options.text: To understand the physics behind the satellite's movement.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of Einstein's theory of relativity in determining the location of the smartphone?

options.label: B
options.text: It is used to calculate the speed of the satellite.

options.label: C
options.text: It is used to correct the measurements.

options.label: D
options.text: It is used to determine the location of the satellite.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why a smartphone can determine its location using GPS satellites?

options.label: A

options.label: C
options.text: Because it has a multibillion-dollar network of satellites.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it has a smartphone app.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the smartphone, GPS satellites, and quantum mechanics?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: The nobles and clergy never paid taxes

options.label: C
options.text: The taxes were too high for the common people

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: A promise to support the nobles

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.text: A declaration of independence for the French colonies

options.label: B

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: What triggers a chemical reaction? - Kareem Jarrah

multiple-choice.question: What are enthalpy and entropy, and what is their big idea?

options.label: A
options.text: They are the names of the two main characters in a chemistry textbook.

options.label: B
options.text: They are the names of the two main forces that control chemical reactions.

options.label: C
options.text: They are the names of the two main types of chemical bonds.

options.label: D
options.text: They are the names of the two main types of chemical reactions.

multiple-choice.question: What is enthalpy?

options.label: A
options.text: A measure of a chemical's randomness.

options.label: B
options.text: An increase or decrease of energy during a chemical reaction.

multiple-choice.question: What is an exothermic reaction?

options.label: A
options.text: A reaction where the final energy is greater than the starting energy.

options.label: B
options.text: A reaction where the final energy is less than the starting energy.

options.label: C
options.text: A reaction where the chemical's final energy is equal to its starting energy.

options.label: D
options.text: A reaction where the chemical's final energy is not affected by the starting energy.

multiple-choice.question: What is entropy?

options.label: A
options.text: A measure of a chemical's stability.

options.label: B
options.text: A measure of a chemical's randomness.

multiple-choice.question: What is an endothermic reaction?

options.label: A
options.text: A reaction where the final energy is greater than the starting energy.

options.label: B
options.text: A reaction where the final energy is less than the starting energy.

options.label: C
options.text: A reaction where the chemical's final energy is not affected by the starting energy.

options.label: D
options.text: A reaction where the chemical's final energy is equal to its starting energy.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the golf ball analogy in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To explain the concept of enthalpy.

options.label: B
options.text: To explain the concept of entropy.

options.label: C
options.text: To explain the difference between exothermic and endothermic reactions.

options.label: D
options.text: To explain the concept of chemical bonds.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between enthalpy and entropy in a chemical reaction?

options.label: A
options.text: Enthalpy and entropy are two independent factors that control chemical reactions.

options.label: B
options.text: Enthalpy and entropy are two related factors that control chemical reactions.

options.label: C
options.text: Enthalpy and entropy are two opposing factors that control chemical reactions.

options.label: D
options.text: Enthalpy and entropy are not related to chemical reactions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the example of a reaction that demonstrates the relationship between enthalpy and entropy?

options.label: A
options.text: The combustion of hydrogen and oxygen.

options.label: B
options.text: The reaction between baking soda and vinegar.

options.label: C
options.text: The reaction between a match and wood.

options.label: D
options.text: The reaction between a chemical and water.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of entropy on a chemical reaction?

options.label: A
options.text: Entropy decreases the likelihood of a reaction.

options.label: B
options.text: Entropy increases the likelihood of a reaction.

options.label: C
options.text: Entropy has no effect on the likelihood of a reaction.

options.label: D
options.text: Entropy decreases the energy of the reaction.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between exothermic and endothermic reactions?

options.label: A
options.text: Exothermic reactions require more energy than endothermic reactions.

options.label: B
options.text: Exothermic reactions require less energy than endothermic reactions.

options.label: C
options.text: Exothermic and endothermic reactions require the same amount of energy.

options.label: D
options.text: Exothermic and endothermic reactions are not related.

title: Could a blind eye regenerate? - David Davila

multiple-choice.question: What happens to a person's field of vision in the case of diseases like Retinitis pigmentosa and Usher syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: It becomes slightly larger, widening or brightening.

options.label: B
options.text: It becomes slightly smaller, narrowing or dimming until eventually they go completely blind.

options.label: C
options.text: It remains the same, with no change in brightness or size.

options.label: D
options.text: It disappears, and they lose their ability to see.

options.label: B

options.label: B
options.text: They remain the same, with no change.

options.label: C
options.text: They are steadily lost until the screen in the eye can no longer detect light nor broadcast signals to the brain.

options.label: D
options.text: They are replaced by new photoreceptors.

multiple-choice.question: Which animal can grow back its skin, bones, heart, and retina after they've been damaged?

options.label: A
options.text: Less like Müller cells and more like photoreceptors.

options.label: B
options.text: Less like Müller cells and more like stem cells.

options.label: C
options.text: Less like Müller cells and more like retinal cells.

options.label: D
options.text: Less like Müller cells and more like neurons.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of glutamate and aminoadipate in the transformation of Müller glia into photoreceptors?

options.label: B
options.text: They have no role in the transformation.

options.label: C
options.text: They make the Müller glia divide and transform into photoreceptors.

options.label: D
options.text: They make the photoreceptors multiply and grow.

multiple-choice.question: What is the question that scientists are trying to answer to understand how to trigger the transformation of Müller glia in the human eye?

options.label: A
options.text: How do we prevent the transformation of Müller glia?

options.label: B
options.text: How do we make the Müller glia divide and transform into photoreceptors?

options.label: C
options.text: How do we trigger the transformation of Müller glia in the human eye?

options.label: D
options.text: How do we replace the Müller glia with new photoreceptors.

title: How spontaneous brain activity keeps you alive - Nathan S. Jacobs

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the brain?

options.label: C
options.text: To process every single thing we experience, our thoughts and our actions

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated number of neurons in the brain?
What is the term for the complex rhythms of internally generated brain activity?
What is the primary function of central pattern generators?
What is the term for the stage of sleep characterized by rapid eye movements and vivid dreams?
What is the primary function of the retinal ganglion cells in the retina?

options.label: A
options.text: To translate light into neural signals

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the ongoing activity in multiple parts of the brain that helps it interpret and respond to any signals it might receive?

options.label: D

title: How do vaccines work? - Kelwalin Dhanasarnsombut

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the immune system in defending against contagious diseases?

options.label: A
options.text: To produce antibodies that neutralize pathogens.

options.label: B
options.text: To trigger a series of responses to identify and remove foreign microbes.

options.label: C
options.text: To increase the body's temperature to kill pathogens.

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce inflammation and prevent infection.

What is the purpose of vaccines in preparing the body's immune response?

options.label: A
options.text: To expose humans to the full strength disease.

options.label: B
options.text: To trigger the body's adaptive immune system without exposing humans to the full strength disease.

options.label: C
options.text: To reduce the severity of the disease.

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the body's temperature to kill pathogens.

multiple-choice.question: What type of vaccine is made from a weakened or killed pathogen?

options.label: A
options.text: To trigger a strong immune response by using the entire pathogen.

options.label: B
options.text: To prompt specific responses by isolating specific components of antigens.

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce the severity of the disease.

multiple-choice.question: What type of vaccine is made from specific genetic material that instructs cells in the body to make antigens?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The eight-year-old boy was inoculated against the disease.

options.label: D
options.text: The disease spread to the entire community.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary benefit of DNA vaccines?

options.label: A
options.text: They are easy to make and can be used by people with weaker immune systems.

options.label: B
options.text: They trigger a strong immune response and prepare the body for any future threats.

options.label: D
options.text: They reduce the severity of the disease.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential impact of continued development of vaccines?

options.label: A
options.text: We might be able to treat diseases like HIV, malaria, or Ebola.

options.label: B
options.text: We might be able to develop new treatments for invasive pathogens.

options.label: C
options.text: We might be able to increase the body's temperature to kill pathogens.

options.label: D
options.text: We might be able to reduce inflammation and prevent infection.

options.text: A type of canoe used for transportation.

options.text: A type of shell necklace used for trade.

options.label: C
options.text: A system of trade used by the natives of the Trobriand islands.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of arm band used for trade.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between a gift economy and a barter system?

options.label: A
options.text: The main difference is that the original gift is given without any preconditions or haggling.

options.label: B
options.text: The main difference is that the original gift is given with preconditions or haggling.

options.label: C
options.text: The main difference is that the gift economy is used to accumulate material wealth and the barter system is used to accumulate social wealth.

options.label: D
options.text: The main difference is that the gift economy is used to accumulate social wealth through the use of money and the barter system is used to accumulate wealth without the use of money.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of a potlatch feast?

options.label: B
options.text: To accumulate social wealth by giving away livestock and blankets.

multiple-choice.question: What is the key to maintaining a gift economy?

options.label: A
options.text: Repaying a gift immediately or with something of exactly equal value.

options.label: B
options.text: Keeping the gift cycle going, with someone always indebted to someone else.

multiple-choice.question: Are gift economies exclusive to small-scale societies outside the industrialized world?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, they are exclusive to small-scale societies outside the industrialized world.

options.label: B
options.text: No, they are not exclusive to small-scale societies outside the industrialized world.

options.label: C
options.text: Gift economies exist in some small-scale societies outside the industrialized world, but they also exist in some parts of the industrialized world.

options.label: D
options.text: Gift economies do not exist in the industrialized world.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a gift economy emerging as an alternative to intellectual property?

options.label: A
options.text: A market economy where artists and musicians sell their creative works for financial profit.

options.label: B
options.text: A gift economy where artists and musicians distribute their creative works for free.

options.label: C
options.text: A barter system where artists and musicians trade their creative works for goods and services.

options.label: D
options.text: A commercialized system where artists and musicians sell their creative works for financial profit.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a gift economy existing in a communal space?

options.label: A
options.text: A market economy where people buy and sell goods and services.

options.label: B
options.text: A gift economy where people give and receive gifts without expecting anything in return.

options.label: C
options.text: A barter system where people trade goods and services for other goods and services.

options.label: D
options.text: A commercialized system where people accumulate material wealth.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a gift economy existing in a holiday tradition?

options.label: A
options.text: A market economy where people buy and sell gifts.

options.label: B
options.text: A gift economy where people give and receive gifts without expecting anything in return.

options.label: C
options.text: A barter system where people trade gifts for other gifts.

options.label: D
options.text: A commercialized system where people accumulate material wealth.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main point of a gift economy?

options.label: C
options.text: To strengthen bonds through giving and reciprocity.

options.label: D
options.text: To weaken bonds through giving and reciprocity.

title: The Atlantic slave trade: What too few textbooks told you - Anthony Hazard

options.label: B

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The continent remained the same in terms of population

options.label: D
options.text: The continent gained a large population of women and children

multiple-choice.question: What was the effect of the Atlantic slave trade on the demographics of the Americas?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: How to create cleaner coal - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What is the main culprit behind global climate change?

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the main advantage of using CCS?

options.text: It reduces coal's emissions by up to 90%.

title: The 2,400-year search for the atom - Theresa Doud

multiple-choice.question: Who first proposed that everything in the world was made up of tiny particles surrounded by empty space?
What did John Dalton conclude about the composition of substances?

options.label: A
options.text: That they were made of four elements: earth, wind, water, and fire.

options.label: B
options.text: That they were combinations of atoms of different elements, each of a particular size and mass.

options.label: C
options.text: That they were made of tiny particles surrounded by empty space.

options.label: D
options.text: That they were made up of a single element.

multiple-choice.question: What did J.J. Thompson's discovery of the electron show about the atom?

options.label: A
options.text: That atoms were made up of a single element.

options.label: B
options.text: That atoms were composed of uniformly packed spheres of positive matter filled with negatively charged electrons.

options.label: C
options.text: That atoms were made up of four elements: earth, wind, water, and fire.

options.label: D
options.text: That atoms were combinations of atoms of different elements, each of a particular size and mass.

multiple-choice.question: What did Ernest Rutherford conclude about the composition of atoms?

options.label: A
options.text: That they were made up of a single element.

options.label: B
options.text: That they were combinations of atoms of different elements, each of a particular size and mass.

options.label: C
options.text: That they consisted largely of empty space with just a few electrons, while most of the mass was concentrated in the center, which he termed the nucleus.

options.label: D
options.text: That they were made up of four elements: earth, wind, water, and fire.

multiple-choice.question: Who expanded on Rutherford's nuclear model and stipulated that electrons orbit the nucleus at fixed energies and distances?
What did Werner Heisenberg show in formulating his famous uncertainty principle?

options.label: A
options.text: That it was possible to determine both the exact position and speed of electrons as they moved around an atom.

options.label: B
options.text: That electrons cannot be pinpointed but exist within a range of possible locations.

options.label: C
options.text: That electrons orbit the nucleus at fixed energies and distances.

options.label: D
options.text: That atoms are made up of a single element.

multiple-choice.question: What is the current quantum model of the atom based on?

options.label: A
options.text: The idea that electrons orbit the nucleus at fixed energies and distances.

options.label: B
options.text: The idea that electrons cannot be pinpointed but exist within a range of possible locations.

options.label: C
options.text: The idea that atoms are made up of four elements: earth, wind, water, and fire.

options.label: D
options.text: The idea that atoms are combinations of atoms of different elements, each of a particular size and mass.

multiple-choice.question: What is the basic fact of atoms that remains unchanged despite our evolving understanding of them?

options.label: A
options.text: That they are made up of four elements: earth, wind, water, and fire.

options.label: B
options.text: That they are combinations of atoms of different elements, each of a particular size and mass.

options.label: C
options.text: That they consist largely of empty space with just a few electrons, while most of the mass is concentrated in the center.

options.label: D
options.text: That they exist in a single element.

title: How does cancer spread through the body? - Ivan Seah Yu Jun

multiple-choice.question: What is the process called when cancer spreads across the body?

options.text: The vascular and lymphatic channels theory

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the process of cancer cells spreading via the lymphatic system?

options.text: The vascular and lymphatic channels theory

What is the term for the constant struggle against cancer?
